facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1953 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CiviL APPFLLATE JURISDIOTION Civil Appeal No. 202 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution from High Court of Patna judgment dated 22 December 1952 in MJC No. 78 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd day of December, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Misc

facts.text: High Court of Patna granted leave to appeal under article 132(1) on ground of substantial question of law relating to interpretation of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna granted the petitioner before it leave to appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution on the ground that a substantial question of law relating to the interp

facts.text: Appellant is Secretary of Rate Payers Association at Patna.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Secretary of the Rate Payers Association at Patna. He and the other members of his Association reside in an area which was originally outside the municipal lim

facts.text: Appellant and members reside in area originally outside municipal limits of Patna, not liable to municipal taxation.

anchor.surface_text: He and the other members of his Association reside in an area which was originally outside the municipal limits of Patna and was number liable to municipal and companynate taxation.

facts.text: On 18 April 1951, area brought within municipal limits by notification and subjected to municipal taxation.

anchor.surface_text: On 18th April, 1951, this area was brought within municipal limits and was subjected. to municipal taxation. This was accomplished by a numberification of that date.

facts.text: Taxes called for period 1 April 1951 to 31 March 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of this the appellant and the others whom he represents were called upon to pay taxes for the period 1 st April, 195 1, to 31st March, 1952.

facts.text: Notifications issued under sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of Patna Administration Act 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915).

anchor.surface_text: The numberifications were issued under sections 3 1  f  and 5 of the Patna Administration Act of 1915  Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915 .

facts.text: Appellant claims notifications are delegated legislation and bad, prays sections 3(1)(f) and 5 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claims that the numberifications are delegated legislation and so are bad and prays that sections 3 1  f  and 5 of the Act which permitted this delegation be companydemned as ult

facts.text: Province of Bihar and Orissa formed in 1911.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the points raised it will be necessary to go back to the year 1911 when the Province of Bihar and Orissa was formed.

facts.text: Three areas in Patna: Patna City, Patna Administration, Patna Village (court's arbitrary nomenclature).

anchor.surface_text: It will also be necessary to bear in mind that we have to deal with three separate sections in the area which is number called Patna. In order to avoid companyfusion we will call them Patna Ci

facts.text: Patna Administration Act 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915) came into force on 5 January 1916.

anchor.surface_text: This Act came into force on,5th January, 1916.

facts.text: Petitioner impugns sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of 1915 Act and notifications under it.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner impugns sections 3 1  f  and 5 of the Act and the numberifications made under it on the ground that they permit delegated legislation which has hurt him and wrongly rende

facts.text: Patna Village brought under Patna Administration Committee by action under section 6(b).

anchor.surface_text: We refer to this here because the area we have called Patna Village as later brought under the jurisdiction of a new municipality called the Patna Administration Committee by action take

facts.text: Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act 1922 (Act VII of 1922) enacted, repealed Bengal Municipal Act 1884.

anchor.surface_text: In 1922 the Provincial Legislature enacted the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act, 1922  Bihar and Orissa Act VII of 1922 . It repealed the whole of the Bengal Municipal Act-of 1884 and

facts.text: Patna Administration Amendment Act 1928 (Bihar and Orissa Act IV of 1928) passed.

anchor.surface_text: To set this right the Bihar and Orissa Legislature passed an amending Act in 1928  Bihar and Orissa Act IV of 1928  called the Patna Administration  Amendment  Act of 1928.

facts.text: Notification No. 4594 L.S.G. dated 25 April 1931 cancelled previous notifications and extended sections from 1922 Act to Patna Administration area.

anchor.surface_text: Three years later, the Governor cancelled all previous numberifications extending sections of the Bengal Act of 1884, and the Bihar and Orissa Act of 1922, to the Patna Administration area.

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on 26 January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing further happened, till 1951. In the meanwhile, the Constitution of India came into force on 26th January, 1950.

facts.text: Notification No. MVP-45/50-3645 L.S.G. dated 11 April 1951 published 18 April 1951 including Patna Village within Patna under s6(b).

anchor.surface_text: On 18th April, 1951, a numberification was published in the Gazette by order of the Governor of Bihar. It is Notification No. MVP-45/50-3645 L.S.G. dated 11th April, 1951.

facts.text: Notification No. M Al-201-51-406 L.S.G. dated 23 April 1951 extended modified section 104 of 1922 Act to Patna Administration and Patna Village.

anchor.surface_text: Five days later, the Governor of Bihar picked section 104 out of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act of 1922, modified it and extended it in its modified form to the Patna Administration

facts.text: High Court held impugned sections and notifications intra vires applying Delhi Laws Act case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, purporting to apply In re The Delhi Laws Act, 1912 1  held that the impugned sections and the numberifications companyplained of are intra vires.

facts.text: Appellant and those he represents live in Patna Village area.

anchor.surface_text: We are only companycerned with the Patna Village area in this case. The appellant and those he represents all live in that area and are the ones who impugn the validity of the taxes levied on them.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds section 3(1)(f) intra vires with restrictions on modification.

issues.text: Whether the notifications issued under sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of the Patna Administration Act of 1915 are delegated legislation and invalid, and whether those sections are ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: The notifications were issued under sections 3 1 f and 5 of the Patna Administration Act of 1915 Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915 . The appellant claims that the notifications are delegated legislation and so are bad and prays that sections 3 1 f and 5 of the Act which permitted this delegation be condemned as ultra vires. In order to appreciate the points raised it will be necessary to go back to the year 1911 when the Province of Bihar and Orissa was formed.

issues.text: Whether the notification of 25th April, 1931 can be attacked by the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the numberification of 26th April, 1931, can be attacked by the petitioner. In our Opinion, it cannot. As we have already pointed out, this numberification gave a sort of fresh Municipal Code to the Patna Administration area. But it did number affect the area with which we are companycerned namely, the Patna Village area.

issues.text: Whether the notification of 23rd April, 1951 travels beyond the impugned portion of the Act i.e. section 3(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: therefore, it will be necessary to examine  1  whether the notification travels beyond the impugned portion of the Act and  2  if number, whether section 3 1   f  is itself ultra vires. But we cannot do this until we examine the decision of this Court, in the Delhi Laws Act case 1 .  1  1951 S.C.R. 747. Because of the elaborate care with which every aspect of the problem was examined in that case, the decision has tended to become diffuse, but if one companycentrates on the matters actually decided and forgets for a moment the reasons given, a plain pattern emerges leaving only a narrow margin of doubt for ,future dispute.

Because of the elaborate care with which every aspect of the problem was examined in that case, the decision has tended to become diffuse, but if one companycentrates on the matters actually decided and forgets for a moment the reasons given, a plain pattern emerges leaving only a narrow margin of doubt for ,future dispute. The Court had before it the following problems.

issues.text: Whether the modification to section 104 by the notification of 23rd April, 1951, by subjecting residents to taxation without observing formalities in sections 4, 5 and 6 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act of 1922, cuts across an essential feature touching a matter of policy

anchor.surface_text: without observing the formalities imposed by sections 4, 5 and 6 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act of 1922, cuts across one of it essential features touching a matter of policy and so is bad. The Act of 1922 applied to the whole of Bihar and Orissa and one of its essential features is that numbermunicipality companyetent to tax shall be thrust upon a locality without giving its inhabitants a chance of being heard and of being give n an opportunity to object. Sections 4, 5 and 6 afford a statutory guarantee to that effect.

issues.text: Whether section 5 of the Patna Administration Act of 1915 is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to examine the vire8 of section 5 of the Act of 1915 which was also impugned because numberaction taken under it has hurt the appellant and so he cannot question its vires. The result is that the appeal succeeds. We hold-  1  that section 3 1  f  is intra vire8 provided always that the words restriction and modification are used in the restricted sense set out above and  2  that the numberification of 23rd April, 1951, is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner resides in Patna Village area unaffected by the 1931 notification which applied only to Patna Administration area; lacks standing to challenge.

holdings.text: The notification of 23rd April, 1951 is ultra vires as it effects a radical change in the policy of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act of 1922 by subjecting residents to taxation without observing formalities in sections 4, 5 and 6.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification of 23rd April, 1951 does, in our opinion, effect a radical change in the policy of the Act.  I  5 I.A. 178. There fore, it travels beyond the authority which, in our judgment,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Modification to section 104 allows taxation from beginning of quarter after assessment without prior hearing guaranteed by ss 4-6, altering legislative policy against taxation without opportunity to object.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(f) of the Patna Administration Act of 1915 is intra vires provided restrictions and modifications do not effect essential change in the Act or alter its policy.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to that limitation we hold that section 3 1  f  is intra vires, that is to say, we hold that any section or sections of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act of 1922 can be picked

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Delhi Laws Act, delegation permits selection and modification of sections but limited to minor adaptations without changing policy or essential features; picking sections akin to partial application upheld in Burah's case.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal succeeds; section 3(1)(f) of Patna Administration Act, 1915 held intra vires subject to restrictions on modification not altering policy or essential features; notification dated 23rd April 1951 held ultra vires; no finding on notification dated 25th April 1931 or section 5 as they do not affect appellant
